result.execSummary:
The defendant Cesar Hernandez-Lara was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Maintain FTE/schooling or combination of the two, and if not so fully engaged, complete 9 hours community service per week.

Maintain absolute sobriety.

No contact with victims unless approved by agent.

Assessment, treatment, counseling deemed appropriate by agent. 

SAFE intake program and follow through. 

AODA and follow through. 

60/90/120 day probation review hearings. 

DNA sample.  

If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  

A copy of the police report has been electronically sent to the probation office.

I/S to be used for rules violations.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Cesar Hernandez-Lara

records.addlTxt: Probation review hearing on November 18, 2022 at 01:15 pm.
w/Notice of Right to Seek Postconviction Relief

Clerk: Amanda. 
Case called at 10:52 am. 
State appears by ADA Cody Marschall.  Defendant appears, and with Attorney Zach Glascock.

Plea Questionnaire/Waiver of Rights filed.  VRCW.

State moves to: 
Ct.1(Battery/Domestic Abuse)>>DRI.

COURT GRANTS ABOVE.

PLEA to Ct.2(DC/Domestic Abuse)>>NO CONTEST. 

COURT advises defendant of rights (including constitutional rights) & penalties & questions defendant to understanding; 
COURT finds plea & waiver of rights freely & voluntary made,  a factual basis & defendant guilty;

COURT ORDERS: SWH for 1 year probation; CONDITIONS: I/S 30 days MCJ for rule violations.  I/S 30 hours community service for rule violations.  Assessments/Treatment/Counseling deemed appropriate by agent. Maintain full time work/school or combination of the two, and if not so fully engaged, complete 9 hours CS per week. Maintain absolute sobriety.  SAFE Intake Program and follow through.  AODA and follow through.  No contact with victim(s) unless approved by agent.  60, 90, and 100 day review hearings to be held.  Pay CC/DV surcharge.  Pay DNA surcharge and provide sample. 

COURT grants 2 days credit. 
Probation Review Hearing: 11/18 at 1:15 pm. 

Adj: 11:00 am.
Calendar call on June 30, 2022 at 01:00 pm.

Contact, however, may be made through the defendant's attorney. Police escort to retrieve personal property from the residence. 3rd party child exchange through the family resource center.

Clerk: Amanda.
Case called at 3:06 pm. 
State appears by ADA Cody Marschall.  Deft appears, pro se.  Interpreter appears via Zoom.
Date and Time set for IA; VRCW. 

Interpreter Mariana Kralewski sworn and interprets. 

Reading Waived.  Reserve Jurisdiction. 
Court questions deft re: complaint and rights.
Advised Right of Counsel. 

PLEA:  NOT GUILTY. 

COURT ORDERS: $500 signature bond - CONDITIONS: 
- No contact with victim(s):  E.E.R. or residence. Contact includes direct personal or physical and indirect contact by phone, in writing of any kind, entry to the person's residence or place of employment together with contacts through other persons.  Contact, however, may be made through the defendant's attorney.
- Police escort to retrieve personal property from the residence. 
- 3rd party child exchange through the family resource center.
